The group trips and graduates, students or similar , with the exception of those referred to in subparagraph b. Shall be authorized provincial jurisdictions destination and permanence. All members of the contingent must have a negative antigen test upon boarding. Upon return, the members of the contingent must:    i. Carry out an antigen test prior to boarding the return transport. If any of the diagnostic tests are positive, it should be coordinated with the local authorities to isolate the cases and their close contacts.  ii. Those people who do not have a complete vaccination scheme 14 days prior to the start of the trip, must carry out a 7-day isolation and, on their own, a new test that must be reported to the National Surveillance System by the laboratory. The control of the testing will be in charge of the travel company.  b. On retired and retired group trips, all members of the contingent must present a complete vaccination schedule that occurred at least 14 days prior to the start of the trip.    c. Activities in discotheques, dance venues or similar that take place in closed spaces, may use a maximum of 50% of the authorized capacity, except in cases where a lower capacity is expressly provided by current regulations. In addition, they must require those who attend these activities, a complete vaccination schedule that occurred at least 14 days before the activity.    d. Activities in party halls for dances, dances or similar that take place in closed spaces, may use a maximum of 50% of the authorized capacity, except in cases where a lower capacity is expressly provided by current regulations. The entry of non-resident foreigners in the national territory will be carried out through the safe corridors established in the terms of article 16 of Decree No. 260/20 and complementary regulations, except for:    to. people who are affected by the transfer of merchandise by international trade operations of cargo transportation of merchandise, by air, land, sea, river and lake means;  b. carriers and crew of ships and aircraft;  c. the people affected by the operation of flights and medical transfers; Y  d. Persons duly authorized by the National Directorate of Migration, when there are special and accredited humanitarian reasons that warrant it, with the corresponding intervention of the national health authority and the Ministry of Foreign Relations, International Trade and Worship, in the terms established by the regulation.  According to Administrative Decision 1163/2021 , any person who comes from or has been in the African continent or in the affected areas defined by the national health authority in the last 14 days prior to entering the country, will be subject to compliance with the current immigration requirements:    to. Inform your Affidavit if you come from or if you have been in the affected areas defined by the national health authority in the last 14 days.  b. Have completed the vaccination schedule at least 14 days before entering the country.  c. Have a negative PCR test performed in the country of origin within 72 hours prior to entering the country.  d. Get an antigen test upon arrival in the country.  and. Carry out the quarantine provided for in article 7, paragraph d) of Decree No. 260/20 and its amending and complementary regulations, and perform a PCR test on the tenth day after taking a sample from the PCR test at origin, the result of which must be negative, as a condition of completion of mandatory isolation. Measure 3 - The ban on gathering    It is forbidden to take part in a group of more than 10 (ten) persons. Excluded are The National Assembly, the Government, the Council of State, members of the Court of Justice and persons from the care, security and essential services.  The foregoing does not apply to  Groups consisting solely of persons forming a family or household; and  Children under the age of 12.  A person who is in a group as referred to in paragraph 1 is obliged, when so ordered by a uniformed police officer, to immediately continue his journey or to remove himself in the direction indicated by him.  Meetings for work and sectors or activities for which there is a prevention protocol are permitted.  Parties, including house parties, are prohibited.  Assemblies for mourning sessions and funerals are permitted only if and insofar as no more than twenty-five (25) persons are present on the premises at any one time, if the space permits a distance of one and a half metres, and in compliance with the regulations and the prevention protocols of the said activities.  Funeral homes are required to register with the Covid-19 Crisis Management Team.  Prayer houses are open under the condition that, depending on the surface area, in principle no more than 50 persons are in the room at any one time. If the space allows more than 50 people to be present, this is permitted, provided that the regulations and protocols are strictly applied. The government remains in conclave with the places of worship.  Home church services attended by persons from outside the household are not permitted.  Contact sports are allowed for fully vaccinated athletes, subject to applicable prevention protocols. Individual sports and non-contact sports are also permitted. If competitions are started, they must be played without an audience.  The transport of persons by public transport by road or water is only permitted in compliance with the public transport protocol. The compulsory use of masks will be monitored. Compliance with and enforcement of the public transport protocol will be the responsibility of the Ministry of Transport, Communication and Tourism.  Persons who are able to demonstrate that they are providing care may do so on a regular basis, provided they can prove that they are on the public highway for that purpose.  It is forbidden for anyone to consume alcoholic beverages in public and/or to hold up unnecessary positions in the vicinity of shops and supermarkets.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211230103616/https://covid-19.sr/covid-19-maatregelen-maandag-29-november-2021-tot-nader-order/

Measure 6 - Authorised border crossings;    From 29 November 2021 until further notice, the borders will be open for the movement of persons, provided that  the conditions and protocols specific to the relevant country or region from which the person directly comes are met; and  only after the person has obtained the prior approval of the competent Surinamese authorities to travel, whereby the essential nature of the journey to be made will be assessed, subject to the exception in paragraph 5.  As far as determining the conditions and protocols specifically applicable to the relevant country or region from which the person originates, use shall be made of the current incidences of the countries and the circulation of 'variants of concern'. The countries are classified according to risk (low, medium and high). Based on the risk classification, there are specific conditions that a traveller must meet. The risk classification of countries and the applicable conditions and protocols belonging to the risk levels will be further announced by the competent Surinamese authorities. The classification of the countries will be continuously updated. The countries where a so called 'variant of concern' of the SARS-CoV-2 virus is circulating, as indicated by the World Health Organisation (WHO), have in principle been designated as high-risk countries.  Taking into account the provisions of paragraph 1, only the following flights shall be allowed in Surinamese airspace in the period from 29 November 2021 until further notice:  The Netherlands, the Netherlands Antilles, Guyana, French Guiana, Brazil, Panama, Trinidad & Tobago and the United States of America: outbound and inbound flights for cargo and passenger traffic;  Cuba and the Dominican Republic: only inbound and outbound flights for cargo and outbound flights for passengers;  Haiti: no passenger traffic authorised.  From Guyana and French Guiana, waterborne traffic will be allowed until further notice on 29 November 2021.  Travellers who have been fully vaccinated against the SARS-CoV-2 virus will be allowed to travel from Suriname to foreign countries (outbound) and from foreign countries to Suriname (inbound) in the period from 29 November 2021 until further notice, without requiring permission within the meaning of paragraph 1(b) of this article, only if they:  For inbound and outbound passenger traffic: have been demonstrably fully vaccinated against the Covid-19 virus;  For inbound passenger traffic from a high risk country: are in the possession of a negative SARS-CoV-2 RT-PCR test result not older than 48 hours before departure of the (air)craft to Surinam, and on the third day after arrival in Surinam have taken a SARS-CoV-2 antigen test at an official test site accredited by the Ministry of Health;  For inbound passenger traffic from a low or medium risk country: be in the possession of a negative SARS-CoV-2 antigen test result not older than 24 hours before departure of the (air)craft to Suriname or a negative SARS-CoV-2 RT-PCR test result not older than 72 hours before departure of the (air)craft to Suriname;  For all inbound passenger traffic: travellers are advised to go into self or home quarantine seven days after arrival.  Travellers who have not or not fully been vaccinated against the SARS-CoV-2 virus will, in the period from 29 November 2021 until further notice, be allowed to travel from abroad to Suriname (inbound) for essential or repatriation purposes only if they:  Possess a negative SARS-CoV-2 RT-PCR test result not older than 48 hours prior to departure of the (air)craft to Suriname; and  After arrival, go into compulsory hotel quarantine (under guard) for seven days.  Travellers who have not or not fully been vaccinated against the SARS-CoV-2 virus will be allowed to travel abroad (outbound) from Suriname in the period from 29 November 2021 until further notice, provided they travel to their country of birth or residence or a country of which they are a national.  The Surinamese authorities may grant exemption from the requirements of paragraphs 4, 5, 6 and 7 for essential journeys and/or persons from essential professions (expatriates, diplomats, government officials, medical and health care personnel).  For the purposes of this Article, 'fully vaccinated' includes persons who have tested positive for the SARS-CoV-2 virus between 14 days and 3 months, provided that they  have been free of symptoms for at least three days; and  can submit a statement from an infectologist or internist regarding their positive test and their three-day freedom from symptoms, stating the relevant results.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211230103616/https://covid-19.sr/covid-19-maatregelen-maandag-29-november-2021-tot-nader-order/
